image.altText: Salmon in a fish farm enclosure, seen from underwater, image from Tassal.

props.synopsis: Tasmania has a way of wedging politicians between industry and the environment, between jobs and endangered species â€” with Labor and Liberal strategists well aware of the votes which are at stake.

title.children: Three industries, three electorates and Labor facing a political wedge

image.altText: Spirit of Tasmania IV ship in port.

props.synopsis: Tasmania's government has paid for double-page ads across three newspapers to address "frequently asked questions" about why the Spirit of Tasmania ferries are still a long way off operating â€” with Labor saying the ads are a "blatant waste" of money.

title.children: 'Blatant waste': Critics lash double-page ads explaining ferry debacle

image.altText: Wine and cheese platter

props.synopsis: Ever tried shipping something between Tasmania and the mainland? The hefty cost is supposed to be equal to driving goods down a highway, but the 'clunky' old federal scheme designed to ensure that hasn't been working for a while.

title.children: Call to fix Tasmania's 'highway' to help lower cost of state's produce

image.altText: A man in a blue shirt checking a rain gauge.

props.synopsis:
Thousands of Australians contribute data to the Bureau of Meteorology, but it's the Nichols family's multi-generational commitment that sets them apart.

Â

title.children: Farming family recognised for century's worth of rain data

image.altText: Right side profile of a female tuba player.

props.synopsis: As a kid, Rachel Kelly saw "all the other girls play the flute" but after battling to make a decent sound on that, turned to the tuba â€” and now is doing what no other woman has done before.

title.children: Rachel may not be one to blow her own horn, but others happy to celebrate orchestra's milestone

image.altText: Protesters on the water at an anti-salmon farming rally in Tasmania.

props.synopsis: A Coalition government would not ban salmon farming in Tasmania's Macquarie Harbour even if the Maugean skate's threatened species' status is upgraded to "critically endangered", Peter Dutton says, as people take to the water in protest at the industry.

title.children: Dutton backs salmon farming even if threatened species status worsens

image.altText: Two macaque monkeys sit on a wall.

props.synopsis: A visit to the 'monkey park' has been a part of this Tasmanian city's appeal since the late 1800s, so what is the history of Launceston's Monkey Island? And does it have a future?

title.children: Did you miss? ðŸ“£How Launceston got its monkeys â€” and why they could be gone within decades

image.altText: A close up of Anthony Albanese in a suit.

props.synopsis: The taskforce, belatedly created by the Albanese government after Friday's arson attack on a synagogue in Melbourne, follows more than a year of what one senior Jewish community leader condemns as "paralysis by indecision".

title.children: Under pressure Albanese calls in an anti-Semitism fighting squad

image.altText: Firefights walk past fire damage and smashed glass at the Synagogue.

props.synopsis: After it was declared a "likely terrorist incident", Australia's key security agencies are being brought together to investigate the arson attack on the Adass Israel Synagogue in Melbourne.

title.children: What we know about the synagogue terror attack investigation

image.altText: A doctor sitting behind a desk. Subtitles say 'Do you honestly think metformin is the answer by now?'

props.synopsis: Online scammers are exploiting the faces and names of real Australian doctors to sell dietary supplements and peddle harmful medical advice, putting patients' health at risk.

title.children: Melbourne doctor finds himself at centre of deepfake scam

image.altText: People on platform and at the departures board at Sydney's Central train station

props.synopsis: It's the RBA's latest buzzword for justifying why interest rates need to remain at restrictive levels. But while everyone agrees we have a productivity problem, solving it is another challenge entirely.

title.children: The productivity conundrum that will stop RBA from a festive rate cut

image.altText: A composite image of Ted O'Brien and Chris Bowen.

props.synopsis: The debate over Australia's energy future took place on 7.30 with Ted O'Brien making "assurances" for the opposition when it came to costings.

title.children: 'Deeply offensive': Bowen rebukes Dutton over CSIRO comments

image.altText: A person on a boat wearing a safety vest, high vis clothing and a helmet uses binoculars to monitor a ship.

props.synopsis: The spotting of Chinese warships near Taiwan follows President Lai Ching-te's tour of the Pacific, including the US state of Hawaii, which has angered Beijing.

title.children: Taiwan's military on high alert as Chinese warships sail near island

image.altText: A young woman sits smiling at a desktop computer

props.synopsis: These days, just about everything is being done online. But new research highlights how hard that's making life for thousands of Australians still living without phone and internet.

title.children: Remote Aboriginal communities left offline in digital age shift

image.altText: Dawn Fraser smiling with hands up in the air.

props.synopsis: The 87-year-old is considered one of the greatest swimmers of all time after winning Olympic gold in the 100m freestyle across three games.

title.children: Olympic swimming legend Dawn Fraser recovering after fall, says daughter

image.altText: Woman with black hair with face blurred outside looks out green fence

props.synopsis: Kayla, whose name has been changed, is one of four transgender women transferred interstate into a New South Wales immigration detention facility this year.

title.children: Transgender woman in detention feels trapped in 'horrific' conditions

image.altText: Close up, side shot of Mark Butler.

props.synopsis: Health Minister Mark Butler has called out "product phoenixing" â€” when health insurers close existing "gold" policies to new customers, but then introduce new, almost identical policies at a higher cost.

title.children: Minister vows crackdown on insurance charge loophole

image.altText: A court sketch of a man holding a cloth, half covering his face

props.synopsis: A repeat violent offender with 'one of the worst' records seen by a Supreme Court judge will be released from prison in two days; despite admitting he may not be able to comply with a supervision order.

title.children: Violent offender repeatedly asks if he can 'stay in jail' during hearing ahead of release

image.altText: Cate Blanchett in low light, very close up, staring right at the camera, looking frightened

props.synopsis: The nominees have been announced with Australians on the list, while Emilia PÃ©rez and Wicked both received multiple nominations.

title.children: Blanchett and Kidman among Australians nominated for Golden Globes

image.altText: A group of people gathered outside a lit-up white weatherboard house at night.

props.synopsis: In the hours before Suzy Wood died she heard one last song from a choir gathered outside her home. In the days afterwards, it emerged that it wasn't the first time magic had struck at number 27.

title.children: Two deaths 120 years apart, linked by an act of kindness

image.altText: Narrow corridor lined with light timber beams, with a walking person just visible at the end.

props.synopsis: In the throes of a climate and cost-of-living crisis, Breathe Architecture founder Jeremy McLeod says it's time for Australia to rethink its unsustainable housing design "failure". His latest work, on show now at NGV International, shows exactly how we might go about it.

title.children: Australia's houses are the biggest in the world. Here's an alternative

image.altText: The hands of a child drawing with coloured pencils.

props.synopsis: A review into the safety of homeschooling in Queensland has found 35 cases of children living in high-risk environments.

title.children: Homeschooling review after child's death leads to calls for more oversight

image.altText: Children and staffÂ are seen around a rug while playing at a child care centre

props.synopsis: As the Queensland government debates laws to make the state safer, an Australian study spanning more than 20 years finds early preschool interventions can ensure children live a life without crime.

title.children: Preschool intervention dramatically reduces youth crime, study finds

image.altText: A black and white portrait photo of a man looking serious with a moustache.

props.synopsis: The New South Wales government says the artwork infamous murderer Leonard Lawson did on the old walls of Grafton Gaol must go before the site becomes part of a new hospital because it could be upsetting for staff.

title.children: Plan to cover up 'triggering' artwork of comic book killer dismays historians

image.altText: Bali Nine pair, Si Yi Chen and Matthew Norman, sit staring at the camera

props.synopsis: Australians Scott Rush, Matthew Norman, Si-Yi Chen, Martin Stephens, and Michael Czugaj are serving life sentences in Indonesia for their roles in a drug smuggling plot in 2005.Â

title.children: Indonesian president wants Bali Nine men back in Australia by Christmas

image.altText: Sandstone buildings on the University of Melbourne campus.

props.synopsis: The University of Melbourne will repay a total of $72 million to more than 25,000 underpaid staff after a decade of "unlawful" conduct, as part of an agreement with the Fair Work Ombudsman.

title.children: Melbourne Uni to repay $72 million after 'unlawful' conduct

image.altText: An aerial shot of people walking around a road with accomodation blocks next to them

props.synopsis: School leavers allegedly assaulted tourists on Rottnest Island and pelted bottles at police, with officers trained in controlling riots and public unrest called in to help restore order on the holiday island.

title.children: Riot police swarm popular Rottnest Island to control partying school leavers

image.altText: A Syrian opposition fighter sits inside an office at the Presidential Palace

props.synopsis: With ousted Syrian President Bashar al-Assad and his family in Russia, his presidential palace is vacant and people are taking selfies and making off with the furniture.

title.children: Inside fallen Syrian leader Bashar al-Assad's now-looted presidential palace

image.altText: A photo of Holly Bowles from the funeral order of service.

props.synopsis: Friends and family â€” some wearing pink and others with blue and yellow ribbons in their hair â€” have gathered to farewell Holly Morton-Bowles, who died after consuming methanol-laced drinks in Laos.

title.children: 'In our hearts forever': Holly Morton-Bowles farewelled

image.altText: A man wearing a black jacket and shirt, with a red tie, sits at a table.

props.synopsis: Siaosi Sovaleni is stepping down as Tonga's prime minister with less than a year until the country's next election.

title.children: 'Nothing personal': Tonga PM announces 'surprise' resignation ahead of no-confidence vote

image.altText: A National Assembly staff sprays fire extinguishers to block South Korean soldiers

props.synopsis:
The head of South Korea's high-ranking official corruption investigation office has ordered a travel ban for President Yoon Suk Yeol, who is under investigation for his declaration of martial law last week.

Â

title.children: South Korea orders travel ban for President Yoon

image.altText: Jay-Z

props.synopsis: Music mogul Jay-Z has slammed a civil lawsuit accusing him of raping a 13-year-old girl in 2000 along with Sean "Diddy" Combs, calling the allegations "idiotic" and accusing the lawyer behind the lawsuit of blackmail.

title.children: Jay-Z accused of raping 13-year-old girl with Diddy

image.altText: Adeang and Albanese shake hands and smile inside the prime minister's office at parliament house.

props.synopsis: Australia and Nauru have signed a landmark new treaty which will see the federal government provide $140 million in budget and security support to the Pacific Island country over the next five years â€” with a condition no "third party" nation be involved in its security and key infrastructure.

title.children: Australia inks treaty with Nauru locking out growing Chinese influence

image.altText: Two men wearing hard hats stand among rubble and debris in Indonesia

props.synopsis: Torrential rains have caused rivers to burst their banks, tearing through more than 170 villages in Sukabumi district of West Java province.

title.children: Indonesia landslides and floods leave 10 people dead, two missing
